title: So lemme get this straight...

replies.body:
Some thoughts on the current state of Sona:

1. There are a number of Sona players who find Sona unsatisfying and feel she needs to be buffed, including some players posting on Boards who've felt that way at least since her rework last year.

2. Sona's performance in game, outside of organized professional play, is in a pretty reasonable spot, even in high Elo solo queue. She's also got a bit of the Amumu/Yi effectiveness by Elo curve going on, where she'll be pretty dominant in average games if she's a strong pick in high tier play. That matches up with her play rate, which is quite a bit higher (2-3 times on average, depending on the region) in average Elo ranges versus high Elo. That puts Sona at a pretty average play rate at most tiers of play, though does mean she's underrepresented in high tier play..  

3. Sona's got a kit design that makes it really hard for her power to be satisfying. Her power's split between spell casts that affect multiple targets, auras that can affect multiple allies and power chord effects. That means each individual effect has to be pretty weak and therefore hard to feel, let alone feel good about.
4. Sona's got a really high reliability kit. Provided you've got at least a moderate handle on how her kit works you're going to see fairly consistent output from her. Because her lows aren't very low that also contrains our ability to give her high highs. 

5. Sona's auras are powerful ally buffing effects with a high uptime. That means if solo lane Sona's ever in a spot where she's a solid, satisfying pick duo lane Sona's almost certainly pretty overpowered (since she's able to access her full effectiveness by contrast). That issue could potentially be addressed by adding a mechanic to Sona that's only useful if she's solo laning, though that runs the risk of feeling really forced and post laning adds yet another mechanic to a kit that's already splitting its power into a lot of pieces as above.

6. In terms of where that leaves us we could introduce some less reliable abilities and concentrate power (e.g. by removing auras, power chord or multi hit spells and in exchange buffing the remaining elements) to address points 3 and 4 above. That would lead to a drastically different Sona however. There might also be room for some small QoL or buffs, and I expect Sona will be discussed again internally after preseason follow up's on a good track (though I'm personally doubtful we've got much power to work with and simply buffing Sona until she feels good's going to set her up for a nerf).

First off, thank you for the reply.

And for the actual response: Don't you guys think you sort of...*over-nerfed* Sona, though? There's a lot of points that are just off with the character.

- She's lacking basic fundamental parts that most supports have. Primarily, she has no hard cc outside of her ult. Yea, guaranteed damage allows her to just pube-stomp lower elo players that don't properly understand punishing bad moves or taking advantage of squishier enemies, but in higher elos, there's instances where I *literally have no power* to stop the enemy lane from just walking all over me and my adc. Lux has a root. Morgana has a root. Karma has a root. Lulu has polymorph. Nami has a stun. Even Annie can just point-n-click someone down after a few spells with Q. Sona has even less options for saving herself or her adc than champs that don't even have the support tag. It's the same reason why Kayle doesn't even see relevant bot lane play. It makes it so that Sona can't set up a situation or diffuse a situation outside of throwing out Q's, waiting for level 6.

- As Sona is now, the primary way people get by at higher levels of play is basically heavy ap investment with a Lich. It's pretty much the only thing that Sona can do that gives her a role that other supports can't just walk all over: guaranteed Lich procs. Seeing how she's primarily a support, it's awkward when you have to hesitate when considering building things like Locket and Frozen Heart...since as much as your team may need it, it'll make Sona herself significantly less valuable to her team.

She's extremely slow (325), extremely squishy, and extremely short-ranged with only one weak damage move outside of her ult, with no hard cc at all outside of that same ult. People have the notion that she's not interactive to play against, but it's literally quite the opposite. Playing Sona is like constantly dancing on a fine line where I could quite quickly be torn to shreds in seconds. Her effective range for her damage is 550 (since it needs the autos), and her range for her aura is 350 (causes clumping), yet there's a very noticeable lack of reward for having to be within nearly every champ's engaging/trading ranges to just...function properly. Meddler, I do not mean any disrespect, but I feel that several of your points are invalid. If we were talking about the Sona that existed back in June 2014 and further back, then I would agree with most of what you said. However, I can't help but disagree with "Sona's auras are powerful ally buffing effects with a high uptime". Post rework, the biggest complaint I've heard from various Sona players is about her new auras feeling nowhere near as impactful, and that her cooldowns feel too long. With her rework in July, you basically made Sona an infinitely worse champion just because she appeared in pro play once. She lost an AD/AP aura for a short duration aura for on hit magic damage, which most mages and AP assassins like LeBlanc won't make much use of. She then lost an Armor/MR aura for a shield that shields too weak and has too long of a downtime to matter much. Her powerchords, while remaining similar to before, don't feel nearly as impactful as playing any other support, as I could just stun or silence them with pratically any other support, without using my ultimate. The two biggest issues I see with Sona right now is how reliable her kit is, and how spread out her "strengths" are.

Champions with reliable kits end up in one of three states: They are either underwhelming, blatantly broken, or they are gated by requiring core items before they become more relevant. Irelia and Jax with triforce are a good example of the third one, as their kits are fairly straightforward with a lot of value, but they don't hit their stride too well unless they grab Triforce. The balancing issue this makes for having this level of reliability and consistency on a support is because their first ~4k gold goes into a support item for ~2200, ~800 for sightstone, and ~800-1000 for boots. If a support is spending a triforce's worth of gold without getting much personal gain to their skills and kit for it, then they're left in a position where they can only be underpowered or broken. Even if Sona were to become good by rushing lichbane, that's still 3000 gold on a support budget before you get sightstone, assuming you don't buy any wards. So while this may improve Sona's combat stats, she loses vision for her team which in turn makes her underwhelming as she has to lose out on supporting utility (wards) to be relevant in lane. One other issue with this is that Sona is the only support who singlehandedly has next to no way of dealing with ganks, her only method being deep wards and running at the sight of trouble. Her E isn't strong enough as a one point wonder to escape a gank, and her only crowd control is her ultimate, which is a waste to burn such a strong ultimate to escape every time you get ganked, especially since every other support has non-ultimate means to deal with a gank.

The next issue is how spread out her strengths are. It's like Sona's a piece of gear in a game with a lot of tiny stats: It's not good at anything. Imagine having a weapon in an MMO that has stats like this: 16-18 damage, +12 hp, +20 mana, +1 mana/sec, +2 armor, +2% lifesteal, +1 vision radius, 10% damage to undead. Compare that to the likes of a weapon that's just 70-80 damage. All the tiny bits of stats here and there would be good in theory if every single stat wasn't near negligible. Other supports like Bard, Thresh, Nami, Leona, etc have innate strength in their kit with crowd control, non-item scaling, and/or stat steroids. They can build a lot more utility based items like Locket, Frozen Heart, etc without their skills becoming irrelevant because they have the added effects. They're more on par with the 70-80 damage weapon, because no matter what, their skills will always be strong. Meanwhile, Sona is stuck in a place where you either go full AP, losing out on a lot of utility items for your team, or you go full support, and Q and W start to feel nowhere near as impactful mid and late game, or you make some hybrid, and end up mediocre at both. The only way I feel that Sona can be made into more than a meme about being a fourth caster minion in a wave is if she gets another rework that adds more counterplay to her kit, so her numbers can feel more impactful and she can have better ways to be balanced. I've contemplated several ways to rework her, adding depth, counterplay, and the ability to make plays and help teammates without being close enough to be AoE nuked, and I would be glad to share some ideas if you wanted me to.
